newsitem.title: USA: New US environmental program gets mixed reviews.
newsitem.headline: New US environmental program gets mixed reviews.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department's final rules for the new Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) got mixed reviews Tuesday, drawing applause from a key farm state lawmaker but criticism from the pork industry.

Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, applauded the final rules as "a victory for Iowa's family farmers," but the National Pork Producers Council said size limits for livestock producers undermined the program.

"Size caps take away from the ability to achieve the real purpose of EQIP by excluding a large sector of the livestock and poultry industries from qualifying for animal waste management dollars," said Jerry King, president of the pork industry trade group.
Earlier, USDA laid out its final rules for the new program, which gives cost-share money and expert advice to producers who want to make environmental and conservation improvements.
USDA said livestock operations with over 1,000 animal units would not be eligible for cost-share aid for waste management.
However, it gave states the ability to modify the national standard to meet their conservation needs.
Beef producers said they were encouraged that the final rule included the flexibility for states to alter the standard.

"The amount of participation in the program remains to be seen, but we are hopeful that farmers and ranchers will be able to partner with government to achieve significant conservation benefits," said Myra Hyde, an official at the National Cattlemen's Beef Association.

Since EQIP was created as part of the 1996 Farm Bill, there has been a dispute over how large a livestock operation could qualify. The program has an annual budget of $200 million through 2002. Half the money is slated for livestock farmers.
